research_topic_title: Impact of HLA-DQ genotype on serology performance for detecting persistent villous atrophy during gluten-free diet monitoring in celiac disease
executive_summary: No published study has directly stratified serology-histology concordance during gluten-free diet follow-up by HLA-DQ genotype, representing a major evidence gap. IgA-tTG2 sensitivity for persistent villous atrophy is only ~50% in unselected populations (meta-analysis of 26 studies), with 53–75% of affected patients seronegative despite strict adherence. HLA-DQ2.5 gene dose strongly predicts higher antibody titers at diagnosis (OR up to 96.9 for DQ2 homozygous), while DQ8 and DQ2.2 patients produce systematically weaker responses — including IgG-class tests (DQ2.2 homo OR=0.72, DQ8 homo OR=0.96 for tTG-IgG, both NS). No major guideline addresses HLA-dependent variation in monitoring serology performance, leaving DQ8/DQ2.2 and seronegative patients without reliable non-invasive monitoring.

key_findings.finding: No study has stratified serology sensitivity for persistent villous atrophy during GFD by HLA-DQ genotype — confirmed by systematic PubMed search returning zero results
key_findings.affected_patient_population: All celiac patients, especially DQ8/DQ2.2 (~10-15% of CD population)

key_findings.finding: IgA-tTG2 sensitivity for persistent villous atrophy on GFD is approximately 50% in HLA-unselected cohorts, replicated across multiple independent studies: 43.6% (Sharkey 2013, n=391), 44.7% (Lau 2017, n=217), 39.7% (Coleman 2021, n=201), 50% (Packova 2020, n=82), 43% pediatric (Leonard 2017, n=103)
EMA-IgA sensitivity for persistent villous atrophy on GFD is comparably poor, confirmed by both meta-analysis and individual studies

DGP-based tests consistently outperform tTG-IgA for detecting persistent villous atrophy: two independent studies show ~67-78% sensitivity vs ~45-50% for tTG. Whether this advantage is HLA-independent is unknown but critical to determine.
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: DGP-POCT 67.1% vs tTG 44.7% (p=0.0005, Lau 2017); aDGP-IgA 77.8% vs tTG 50% (Packova 2020)
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Adults on GFD; if HLA-independent, especially valuable for DQ8/DQ2.2 patients

key_findings.finding: Persistent villous atrophy at 2 years on strict GFD is common even with verified adherence
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: 53% at 2 years (CADER, strict GFD verified by fecal GIP); 34% recovery at 2yr / 66% at 5yr (Rubio-Tapia 2010); 23% persistent VA (Schiepatti 2023, n=694; Coleman 2021, n=368)

key_findings.finding: Majority of patients with persistent villous atrophy have negative serology AND are asymptomatic — creating a silent monitoring failure detectable only by protocol biopsy
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: 75% seronegative and 72.5% asymptomatic among persistent VA cases (CADER); 56.3% seronegative (Lau 2017); 60.3% seroneg tTG (Coleman 2021)
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Adults on GFD with persistent villous atrophy

key_findings.finding: HLA-DQ2.5 gene dose strongly and quantitatively predicts IgA-tTG2 positivity and titer magnitude at diagnosis, spanning a >90-fold OR range
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: OR 96.9 (DQ2 homo), 42.3 (DQ2.5/DQ8), 36.8 (DQ2.5 hetero), NS (DQ2.2 alone). Titers significantly higher homozygous vs heterozygous (p<0.02) vs negative (p<0.01). Low-tTG group 61.8% single heterodimer vs 31.7% high-tTG (p=0.005).
key_findings.affected_patient_population: All celiac patients; DQ8/DQ2.2 most affected

key_findings.finding: Mechanistic basis established: DQ2.5 homozygous APCs present larger repertoire of immunogenic gluten peptides, driving superior T cell proliferation and cytokine secretion. DQ2.2 presents only gamma-gliadin subset; DQ8 narrower still.
IgG-based backup tests follow the same HLA-dependent gradient, closing the alternative diagnostic/monitoring pathway for non-DQ2.5 genotypes
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: DQ2.5 homo OR=10.19 for tTG-IgG; DQ2.2 homo OR=0.72 (NS); DQ8 homo OR=0.96 (NS)
key_findings.affected_patient_population: DQ8/DQ2.2 patients especially with IgA deficiency or low IgG1

key_findings.finding: Serology normalizes months to years before mucosa heals, and seroconversion does not discriminate complete from partial histological recovery
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: ~80% negative serology by 6-12 months vs 34% mucosal recovery at 2 years / 66% at 5 years; seroconversion not different between complete vs partial recovery (p=0.309)

key_findings.finding: DQ2.5 homozygosity overrepresented in refractory celiac disease type II (44% vs 21% uncomplicated CD) and EATL (53%), despite these patients having strongest diagnostic serological response — demonstrating serology eventually fails even in highest-risk HLA group
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: RCD II: 44% DQ2 homo vs 20.7% uncomplicated CD; EATL: 53%. 70-81% of RCD patients seronegative despite ongoing VA.

key_findings.finding: Clinical stakes of persistent villous atrophy are high but contested: Schiepatti 2023 reports HR 9.53 for complications and 2.93 for mortality, while Lebwohl 2013 (larger cohort, longer follow-up) found NO mortality association (HR 1.01, 95% CI 0.86-1.19). Methodological differences may explain discrepancy.
key_findings.quantitative_estimate: HR 9.53 complications (4.77-19.04), HR 2.93 mortality (1.43-6.02) per Schiepatti; HR 1.01 mortality (0.86-1.19) per Lebwohl
key_findings.affected_patient_population: All CD patients with persistent VA

key_findings.finding: D1 (duodenal bulb) biopsies increase detection of persistent villous atrophy by 10.4% beyond D2-only sampling

AGA 2020 seronegative enteropathy guideline explicitly requires follow-up biopsy at 1-3 years for seronegative patients with VA and HLA risk factors; this is the only guideline that addresses the reference patient profile directly

Reference patient (DQ8, Marsh 3A, all serology <1, low IgG1, low secretory IgA) represents convergence of at least five independent monitoring failure mechanisms. Serology-based monitoring is functionally uninformative for this profile.
key_findings.affected_patient_population: Seronegative DQ8 patients with immunoglobulin anomalies

biases_documented.description: Follow-up biopsies often triggered by symptoms or positive serology rather than performed by protocol, systematically underestimating persistent damage in seronegative/asymptomatic patients. Only studies with biopsy-independent-of-serology design (Silvester meta-analysis inclusion criterion, CADER, Lau, Sharkey, Coleman) avoid this.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: High; CADER showed 72.5% persistent VA patients asymptomatic and 75% seronegative — these patients would not receive biopsy under symptom/serology-triggered protocols

biases_documented.bias_type: HLA selection bias in study cohorts
biases_documented.description: Serology-first diagnostic algorithms enrich study populations with high-antibody DQ2.5 genotypes. DQ8/DQ2.2 patients, producing lower or absent serologic responses, are either excluded at diagnosis or underrepresented in follow-up cohorts.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: DQ8/DQ2.2 comprise 10-20% of celiac population but DQ2.2 alone shows no association with tTG-IgA positivity (Choung 2020); these patients are systematically filtered out by serology-first screening

biases_documented.bias_type: Marsh grade spectrum bias during monitoring
biases_documented.description: Persistent damage on GFD skews toward milder Marsh 3a, which elicits lower antibody titers even at diagnosis. The monitoring sensitivity for Marsh 3a-specific persistent VA has never been isolated but is likely well below 40%.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: Significant; tTG titers proportionally lower for milder Marsh grades (p<0.01 for Marsh 3a vs 3c). No study isolates Marsh 3a-specific monitoring sensitivity.

biases_documented.bias_type: Unmeasured HLA heterogeneity as source of between-study variation
biases_documented.description: Individual study sensitivity for tTG during GFD monitoring ranges from 0.12 to 0.75 (Silvester meta-analysis). If study populations differ in DQ2.5 proportion, this could explain much of the heterogeneity. HLA genotype distribution is not reported as a covariate in any monitoring study.
biases_documented.magnitude_estimate: Potentially explains substantial fraction of I-squared heterogeneity

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: Negative IgA-tTG2 during GFD reliably indicates mucosal healing and adequate adherence
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: Pooled sensitivity only 50% (95% CI 41-60%); 56-75% of persistent VA cases seronegative; serology normalizes months-years before mucosa heals; seroconversion does not discriminate complete from partial recovery (p=0.309, Galli 2014)
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: High specificity (~83%, CI 79-87%) means positive tTG-IgA is informative for non-adherence/ongoing damage; persistently positive serology usually indicates ongoing gluten exposure (AGA 2019)
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: False reassurance leading to undetected ongoing damage with potential complication risk

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: Serology monitoring performance is approximately equivalent across HLA-DQ genotypes
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: Strong gene-dose effect across entire mechanistic chain (Vader 2003); >90-fold OR gradient for tTG positivity at diagnosis (Choung 2020); DQ2.2 alone not associated with tTG-IgA positivity; patients with lower titers at diagnosis will normalize faster
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: Airaksinen 2020 found no significant difference in mucosal recovery or antibody positivity at follow-up across DQ2.5 dose groups (though not isolating DQ8-only or DQ2.2-only, and using cross-sectional design). Biology of mucosal healing may be independent of HLA type.
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: If monitoring sensitivity below 30% for DQ8/DQ2.2, serology is functionally uninformative for ~10-15% of celiac patients

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: IgG-based tests adequately compensate in patients with low IgA production or IgA deficiency
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: Same HLA-dependent gradient for IgG tests: DQ2.2 homo OR=0.72 (NS), DQ8 homo OR=0.96 (NS). Low IgG1 subclass further compromises IgG-based detection.
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: No published counterevidence; assumption appears based on extrapolation from diagnostic performance in DQ2.5-predominant populations
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: Eliminates alternative diagnostic/monitoring pathway for DQ8/DQ2.2 patients with IgA deficiency. Reference patient's low IgG1 compounds this failure.

unproven_assumptions_identified.assumption: Standard tTG-IgA cutoff thresholds are equally appropriate across all HLA-DQ genotypes
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_against: Cutoffs calibrated in DQ2.5-dominated populations (85-90%). DQ8 patients may generate levels below assay cutoff even with active mucosal damage, confirmed empirically by reference patient's seronegativity despite Marsh 3A.
unproven_assumptions_identified.evidence_for: No genotype-specific ROC analysis exists; assumption is untested rather than supported
unproven_assumptions_identified.clinical_impact: Genotype-specific cutoffs might improve sensitivity for non-DQ2.5 patients; optimal DGP cutoffs show promise (Packova 2020: optimized aDGP-IgA cutoff reached 72% sens/90% spec)

overlooked_populations.population: DQ8-only celiac patients reliant on serology monitoring
overlooked_populations.why_missed: Weakest serologic response among permissive genotypes; no HLA-stratified monitoring protocols; often excluded by serology-first diagnostic pathways
overlooked_populations.proposed_solution: Routine HLA typing at diagnosis; protocol biopsy at 2 years regardless of serology/symptoms; explore DGP-based tests (potentially HLA-independent); non-antibody biomarkers (I-FABP, citrulline)

overlooked_populations.why_missed: Not even associated with tTG-IgA positivity in largest study (Choung 2020); may be diagnosed incidentally rather than through serology; systematically excluded from serology-triggered monitoring
overlooked_populations.proposed_solution: Same as DQ8-only; consider reclassification of monitoring expectations

overlooked_populations.population: Patients with combined low-risk HLA genotype AND immunoglobulin anomalies (low IgG1, low secretory IgA)
overlooked_populations.estimated_size: Unknown but clinically observed in reference patient
overlooked_populations.why_missed: No guideline distinguishes serum IgA deficiency from selective mucosal/secretory IgA reduction; IgG1 subclass not routinely measured; convergence of multiple low-probability factors
overlooked_populations.proposed_solution: Biopsy-based monitoring only; fecal GIP for adherence verification; investigate Siniscalco 2025 IgM-to-IgG1-to-IgA sequential class switching as explanatory mechanism

diagnostic_step_sensitivity.step_name: IgA-tTG2 detection of persistent villous atrophy during GFD monitoring
diagnostic_step_sensitivity.reported_sensitivity: Often assumed adequate based on diagnostic performance (>90% at diagnosis in DQ2.5-predominant populations)
diagnostic_step_sensitivity.adjusted_sensitivity: 50% pooled (95% CI 41-60%, Silvester 2017); 43.6% (Sharkey, n=391); 44.7% (Lau, n=217); 39.7% (Coleman, n=201); 50% (Packova, n=82); 43% pediatric (Leonard, n=103)
diagnostic_step_sensitivity.false_negative_rate: ~50% overall; likely higher (estimated 60-80%) in DQ8/DQ2.2 subgroups based on mechanistic inference — untested directly
key_limitations: Rapid serology normalization (6-12 months) vs delayed mucosal healing (2-5 years) creates prolonged false-reassurance window
Verification bias in non-protocol biopsy studies inflates apparent sensitivity
HLA genotype variability not measured as covariate — overall sensitivity is average dominated by DQ2.5
Spectrum bias: persistent damage skews toward Marsh 3a, lowest tTG sensitivity even at diagnosis
Seroconversion does not discriminate healed from partially healed (p=0.309, Galli 2014)
IgG backup tests follow same HLA-dependent gradient, closing alternative pathway
Individual study sensitivity ranges 0.12-0.75 — unmeasured population-level confounders (likely HLA distribution)
D1 biopsy increases VA detection by 10.4% (Coleman 2021) — studies using D2-only may underestimate persistent VA, artificially inflating apparent serology sensitivity

contradictory_studies.finding: Pooled IgA-tTG2 sensitivity only 50% (95% CI 41-60%) for persistent VA on GFD across 26 studies
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Clinical practice of using negative serology as evidence of mucosal healing

contradictory_studies.citation: Fernandez-Banares et al. 2021 CADER study (Am J Gastroenterol)
contradictory_studies.finding: 53% persistent VA at 2 years on strict GFD verified by fecal GIP; 75% seronegative; 72.5% asymptomatic
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Assumption that negative serology plus absence of symptoms equals mucosal healing

contradictory_studies.finding: 24,339 adults: >90-fold OR gradient from DQ2 homozygous to DQ2.2 alone; DQ2.2 hetero NOT associated with tTG-IgA positivity
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Uniform serology cutoffs/monitoring strategies applied identically across all HLA-DQ genotypes

contradictory_studies.finding: 7,648 Swedish CD patients: persistent VA NOT associated with mortality (HR 1.01, 95% CI 0.86-1.19) in 11.5-year median follow-up
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Schiepatti 2023 finding that persistent VA carries HR 2.93 for mortality — important contradiction in the evidence base for clinical stakes of monitoring failure

contradictory_studies.finding: 694 patients: persistent VA carries HR 9.53 for complications and HR 2.93 for mortality
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Lebwohl 2013 null mortality finding; methodological differences (retrospective-prospective vs registry-based; different populations/eras) may explain discrepancy

contradictory_studies.finding: Antibody seroconversion not significantly different between complete vs partial histological recovery (p=0.309)
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Use of serology normalization as indicator of mucosal healing

contradictory_studies.citation: Coleman et al. 2021 (J Gastrointestin Liver Dis)
contradictory_studies.finding: 368 patients: tTG-IgA sensitivity 39.7%, EMA 38.1% for persistent VA; explicitly concluded serology, CDAT and Biagi performed poorly
contradictory_studies.contradicts: Guidelines recommending serology-based monitoring as primary follow-up strategy

research_gaps.gap: No prospective study calculating serology sensitivity/specificity for persistent VA stratified by full HLA-DQ genotype during GFD
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Multicenter prospective cohort with protocol biopsies at 1 and 2 years independent of serology/symptoms; full HLA-DQ typing (DQ2.5 homo, DQ2.5 hetero, DQ2.5/DQ2.2, DQ2.2-only, DQ8-only, DQ8/DQ2.5, DQB1*02 alone); fecal GIP adherence verification; tTG-IgA + DGP-IgA/IgG + EMA at each timepoint; primary: tTG-IgA sensitivity within each HLA stratum. ~500-1000 patients for DQ8 subgroup power.

research_gaps.gap: Whether DGP test advantage (67-78% vs 40-50% tTG) is HLA-dependent or independent
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: HLA-stratified analysis of existing Lau 2017 or Packova 2020 cohorts; if DGP is less HLA-dependent, it becomes the preferred monitoring test for DQ8/DQ2.2

research_gaps.gap: Marsh 3a-specific sensitivity of serology during GFD monitoring
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Subgroup analysis stratifying serology performance by Marsh grade at follow-up. Existing cohorts (CADER, Lau, Coleman) may have sufficient data for retrospective analysis.

research_gaps.gap: Time to serology normalization stratified by HLA genotype
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Serial serology at 3, 6, 12, 24 months in prospective cohort; test whether DQ8/DQ2.2 normalize faster, further shortening monitoring window

research_gaps.gap: Genotype-specific cutoff optimization for monitoring tests
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: ROC analysis by HLA genotype within protocol-biopsy cohort. Packova 2020 showed optimized aDGP-IgA cutoff (22.6 U/mL) improved accuracy substantially; genotype-specific optimization could further improve.

research_gaps.gap: Validation of non-antibody biomarkers (I-FABP, citrulline) in HLA-stratified populations
research_gaps.proposed_study_design: Add-on to biopsy cohort; I-FABP reflects enterocyte damage independent of adaptive immune response and may bypass HLA-dependent limitation entirely

differential_diagnoses_relevant.overlap_with_cd: Persistent symptoms/damage on intended GFD; most common cause is inadvertent gluten exposure
differential_diagnoses_relevant.distinguishing_features: NRCD requires excluding gluten contamination (fecal GIP), other VA causes, and confirming original CD diagnosis. HLA-dependent monitoring failure means NRCD may go unrecognized in DQ8/DQ2.2 patients with reassuring serology.

differential_diagnoses_relevant.condition: Refractory celiac disease type I and II
differential_diagnoses_relevant.overlap_with_cd: Severe persistent VA despite strict GFD >12 months; serology typically negative (70-81%)
differential_diagnoses_relevant.distinguishing_features: RCD II: clonal aberrant IELs; DQ2.5 homozygosity enrichment (44% vs 21%). DQ8-only RCD is exceptionally rare and unstudied from monitoring perspective.
Drug history; resolution on withdrawal; may lack IEL increase; HLA-DQ2/DQ8 typically negative

differential_diagnoses_relevant.overlap_with_cd: Villous atrophy, negative celiac serology, may have permissive HLA
differential_diagnoses_relevant.distinguishing_features: AGA 2020 Clinical Practice Update (PMID:33010252) provides systematic approach; HLA-DQ2/DQ8 absence rules out CD; response to GFD and follow-up biopsy at 1-3 years required to distinguish

recommendations.recommendation: Do not use negative IgA-tTG2 alone as evidence of mucosal healing. Clinicians should be aware serology misses approximately half of persistent villous atrophy cases overall, and likely more in DQ8/DQ2.2 genotypes.
recommendations.evidence_basis: Meta-analysis of 26 studies (Silvester 2017): 50% sensitivity (CI 41-60%); replicated by CADER, Sharkey, Lau, Coleman, Leonard independently

recommendations.recommendation: Perform routine HLA-DQ typing at celiac diagnosis. DQ8-only and DQ2.2-only patients should be flagged for modified monitoring with lower biopsy threshold.
recommendations.evidence_basis: Gene-dose effect established mechanistically (Vader 2003) and epidemiologically (Choung 2020: >90-fold OR gradient); IgG backup follows same gradient

recommendations.recommendation: Consider protocol follow-up biopsy at approximately 2 years, independent of serology/symptoms, particularly for: (a) DQ8/DQ2.2 patients, (b) seronegative/low-titer at diagnosis, (c) immunoglobulin anomalies, (d) age >45 at diagnosis. Include D1 biopsies to increase detection by ~10%.
recommendations.evidence_basis: 53% persistent VA at 2yr in strict GFD (CADER); 72.5% asymptomatic, 75% seronegative; D1 adds 10.4% detection (Coleman 2021); AGA seronegative enteropathy guideline already requires 1-3yr biopsy for seronegative patients

recommendations.recommendation: Investigate DGP-based tests as potentially superior monitoring tool, especially for DQ8/DQ2.2 patients. Two independent studies show 67-78% sensitivity vs 40-50% for tTG.
recommendations.evidence_basis: Lau 2017 (67.1% vs 44.7%, p=0.0005); Packova 2020 (77.8% vs 50%). HLA-independence of this advantage is testable from existing cohort data.

recommendations.recommendation: For reference-profile patients (DQ8, seronegative at diagnosis, immunoglobulin anomalies), document serology as uninformative. Periodic biopsy is sole reliable mucosal assessment. Use fecal GIP for adherence verification.
recommendations.evidence_basis: Convergence of five independent failure mechanisms; AGA 2020 seronegative enteropathy guideline (PMID:33010252) already requires follow-up biopsy

recommendations.recommendation: Update major guidelines to include HLA-stratified monitoring recommendations and explicitly acknowledge genotype-dependent serology limitations.
recommendations.target: guideline committees (AGA, ACG, BSG, ESPGHAN, ESsCD)
recommendations.evidence_basis: Zero current guidelines mention HLA-dependent monitoring performance variation; established diagnostic-phase variation + monitoring gap

recommendations.recommendation: Fund the HLA-stratified serology-biopsy concordance study as priority research. Existing cohorts (CADER, Schiepatti, Airaksinen, Sheffield) provide infrastructure.
recommendations.evidence_basis: Zero studies address this directly; strong mechanistic rationale; feasible sample sizes demonstrated

meta_analysis_summary.total_patients: >36000 cumulative (Choung 24,339; Lebwohl 7,648; Schiepatti 2,211(total)/694(analyzed); Airaksinen 605; Sharkey 391; Coleman 368/201; Lau 217; Mubarak 116; Leonard 103; Packova 82; CADER 76; Galli 65; others)
meta_analysis_summary.heterogeneity_notes: High heterogeneity in monitoring sensitivity (individual studies range 0.12-0.75). Key unmeasured sources: (1) HLA genotype distribution — likely most important unmeasured confounder, (2) biopsy timing, (3) adherence verification method, (4) Marsh grade distribution at follow-up, (5) biopsy indication (protocol vs triggered), (6) D1 vs D2-only sampling. Contradictory mortality findings (Lebwohl 2013 vs Schiepatti 2023) may reflect population differences, era effects, or selection bias in who receives follow-up biopsy.
